lines.text: 'Gaylord Esterbrook'... seems to me I've heard or read that name someplace. What do you do?
I write plays.
Er, yes, I have a hobby, too. What I meant was, what do you do for a living?
Write plays. Anything wrong?
No, no; nothing, nothing. You'll pardon me, but it does seem a little trivial for a grown man.
Well, perhaps I'll grow out of it. What do *you* do?
I'm on Wall Street.
Where's that?
I don't know, but my chauffeur finds it every morning.
After you get there, what do you do?
Buy and sell stocks and bonds.
Surely not for a living?
And not a bad one. When stocks go up, I make a little money. When they go down, I make even more.
That all you do?
Well, yes!
Well, who knows; maybe you'll grow out of it, too.
[raises glass]
Here's hoping!
I thought you was in Hollywood.
I'm, ah, out on parole.
Clementine, are you sitting on my hat?

[gets up to look]
So I am. I completely covered it. Well, its a small hat.
A sombrero would have met the same fate.

[speaking to his wife Linda]
Well, now, just what's behind that dark innuendo?
Aint nothing behind me, boss.

[about Linda making Mandy cry]
You needn't feel so proud, I make her cry all the time. It usually ends up with me giving her a check.
I didn't give her a check, I think I just gave her my husband.
In my office we'd list that transaction as petty cash.

[Crying]
I don't want to lose him!
[Gaylord]

Well, I don't want to lose Amanda either, but for a totally different reason. I don't want to have my tombstone cluttered up with the names of my formally beloved wives - it leaves no room for the more important data.
I saw your last picture, Mr. Carrell.
Yes?
Oh, yeah.
What'd ya think?

[sighs]
yeah.

[after spending the night after the play on a park bench]
Hey, you don't look bad for a girl who's just getting up in the morning!
For a man who's been up all night you look great!
Don't get the idea that I'm an authority on girls getting up in the morning.
Well, I'm not the last word on men staying up all night either.

[on phone looking for Mr. Esterbrook]
Hello, Luxury Turkish Bath? Connect me to the department for taking care of gentlemen on the loose. Line's busy? I'll wait.
[door bell rings and she goes to let in Mr. Swift]
Has Mr. Easterbrook been there today? No? Well, if he should be carried in, ask him to call his apartment - if he can talk.
